thread.title: Golf wrap: Brendan Steele on target with a 63 - Golf
thread.title_full: Golf wrap: Brendan Steele on target with a 63 - Golf - NorthJersey.com

author: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS |
title: Golf wrap: Brendan Steele on target with a 63 - Golf
text:
NAPA, Calif. — Brendan Steele had an ideal start to the new PGA Tour season at the Frys.com Open with a round that featured nine birdies, no stress and a simple explanation.
"As weird as it is to say, it was kind of a basic 63," he said.
It gave him a one-shot lead over Jhonattan Vegas in ideal scoring conditions at Silverado, which has such subtle movement in the greens that the course doesn’t always yield low scores even when players have a short iron into the putting surface.
Twenty-eight players shot 68 or better, and one-third of the field was in the 60s.
That included Rory McIlroy (68), who is between two seasons. The world’s No. 3 player had numerous birdie chances and didn’t convert nearly as many as he would have liked. What pleased McIlroy was the quality of his game from tee to green, which was far crisper than it was at the Tour Championship three weeks ago.
"Definitely a step in the right direction today," McIlroy said.
Vegas, who won as a rookie in 2011 at the Humana Challenge, lost his card this year and failed to get it back at the Web.com Tour Finals two weeks ago. He is relying on his limited status as a past champion and sponsor exemptions, so it was important to make the most out of his exemption this week.
Harold Varner III, who joins Tiger Woods as the only players of black heritage on the PGA Tour this year, made a strong rookie debut with a 65. Martin Laird had the best score of the afternoon to join Varner at 65. The group at 66 included Justin Thomas, with Justin Rose among those at 67. 
South Korean shoots 10-under 
INCHEON, South Korea — South Korea’s Sung Hyun Park shot a course-record 10-under 62 to take a four-stroke lead in the LPGA KEB Hana Bank Championship.
Park, 22, birdied three of the last four holes after making six birdies in a seven-hole stretch in the middle of the round on Sky 72’s Ocean Course.
Making her first LPGA Tour start, Park played alongside Michelle Wie and Lexi Thompson and often drove past the long-hitting U.S. stars. Thompson had a 68, and Wie shot 71.
"I thought it was not an easy course, but my tee shots, my iron shots, my putting, everything just went really well," Park said through a translator.
Ranked 54th in the world, Park won the Korea LPGA’s Se Ri Pak Invitational two weeks ago for her third victory of the season.
